summary: Am I the only person who keeps thinking about Tessa Thompson's line "She sits at a table and wants to make sure everyone has...
question: Am I the only person who keeps thinking about Tessa Thompson's line "She sits at a table and wants to make sure everyone has access to it". Like so many celebrities may try to say the right thing to the right people at times but it is clear they are not making that simple effort. (and yes, I know I can say Scarlet Johansson).
answer: SHE MADE A POWER POINT PRESENTATION LIKE GET YOU A GIRL LIKE THAT

tags: she is so confused poor baby
summary: “And complicated things further...You can’t just eat food anymore. You have to snap a picture and then share it with your...
body:
“And complicated things further…You can’t just eat food anymore. You have to snap a picture and then share it with your friends.”

“Is that guacamole on bread?”

“Yas. But at twice the price. I’m going to get so many likes.”

“Wow, the lines to get photos developed must be insane.”

blog.name: windschildfanfictionwriter
blog.title: Writer's First Hiccup
blog.description: Fanfiction: Exploring an already created world with characters who were my childhood heroes. Inviting others to explore it with me.

title: Captain Marvel: Brie Larson
body:
I like Brie Larson. I think she’s confidant and unapologetic and on equal footing with the rest of the stars. She’s got an agenda and that’s cool. She wants to put her message out there for the greater good and she’s using her influence to do that. In much the same way that Robert Downey Jr. did for trans rights in the second Sherlock Films. 

Here’s the thing though: She targeted white males. Which I definitely think was the wrong approach. There is a problem in our society, cultivated over thousands of years, that follows a male dominated, white supremacy umbrella. Its a huge problem and we are all trying to tackle it. All of us. That includes a lot of the ‘what males.’ 

You see, when you target a group, it doesn’t really matter what group it is- You alienate them. 

This is WHY world war II started. Because the winners pointed at Germany and said: Its their fault. They need to pay. 

So they stripped Germany of everything. Every resource, every scrap, and called it fair. Just deserts. So an entire country became impoverished. Starving on the streets. Dying. 

And then they banded together, following a charming man who told them they could eat, they could live, they could thrive, if only they followed him. And that’s exactly what they did. 

Hitler pulled Germany, literally, out of the ashes and bones with nothing to support the country. 

World War II began. 

My point is when you blame one certain group, you undermine how complicated the situation actual is. You isolate them. You ensure that they don’t feel like they belong and that they are not invited to thrive with you. You make it a point that it is white versus everyone which only perpetuates the problem rather than moving to solve it. 

Brie Larson has good intentions, but that’s not always enough. You have to have the right approach. I completely understand why so many people are upset, but its not because Brie Larson has a voice and its not because she has an agenda, its because she attacked one group of people, who happens to make up a large portion of the fandom. Instead of saying she wanted to work towards diversifying those in power or saying that she’d liked to work towards having better opportunities for all races and genders, she specifically says that we need to tear down ‘white males.’ She calls them a problem. She laments over how toxic ‘white males’ are. 

That’s a large group of people from a number of backgrounds, from a variety of different places, from an endless number of cultures… that she’s declaring are to blame. 

And when you blame a group of people, when you alienate and target them, you lock them out of the solution. You, essentially, put a bar over it that says they cannot be part of the solution. 

White males cannot help because they are the problem. Not the culture that has been developed. Not the long history of male initiate that we must all work to overcome. Not the extremely complicated and endless minute events that take place every second of every day between one person and another, between one group and another, no. Just white males. 

And that’s a problem. 

Its easy to play the blame game on an obvious target, but doing so means you become part of the problem rather than the solution. As Martin Luther King states, Hate breeds Hate, only Love can breed love. 

I’m definitely not saying go out and befriend a bully, but don’t turn to the person beside you and kick them in the balls. All you’re doing is making yourself a bully and destroying a potential ally. 

This guy is my favorite and he makes many valid points: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oeqr3Y0sp1M

blog.name: softcassie
blog.title: softcassie
blog.description: Summer of 2018 I bought a one way ticket to California (originally from Texas) and never looked back. Now I live in Orange County with my beautiful girlfriend who is just as morally gray as me. I guess you could say I was a small town girl living in a lonely world who took the midnight train going anywhere. Except the train was a actually a plane and the midnight was actually more like 9 p.m. Nowadays I spend my time smoking hand rolled cigarrettes, eating copius amounts of delicious food and fangirling over Choni in Riverdale and also sometimes stealing string cheese from Starbucks. Basically just gettin gayer since '09. (P.S. If you're reading this, I love you babygirl!)

summary:
ATTENTION ALL LESBIAN/QUEER/GAY IDENTIFYING FOLKS 
My girlfriend came out of the closet last week and it did not go well. I've...
body:
Pay Cassandra Suhar using PayPal.Me

ATTENTION ALL LESBIAN/QUEER/GAY IDENTIFYING FOLKS

My girlfriend came out of the closet last week and it did not go well. I’ve been living with her for several months in her parents vacation house because it’s that or be homeless basically. Now they’re kicking me out and because of all the stress my girlfriend has ended up in the hospital. She has lupus and her immune system is shit. She was already a little sick before she came out and it got progressively worse every day after. The other night she was running a fever of 103 even after being on a Z pac for a few days so I had to bring her here. I am waiting for my massage license to come in the mail so I can work and she normally drivers for Postmates but because she’s I’ll (and I’m now sick bc YAY GERMS ugh) we’re broke and stressed out. She had to pay 150 for an emergency therapy session and parking at this hospital is fucking RIDICULOUS. We need at least $500 to get us back on our feet again. If you have money to spare, we would be forever greatful. Thank you so much. Best wishes💜

tags: i kinda ranted sorry about that
feel free to talk to me about this but please be kind
summary: Let’s be honest, here. Captain Marvel was a fun, vibrant and empowering movie, but Carol didn’t have a character arc, the...
body:
Let’s be honest, here. Captain Marvel was a fun, vibrant and empowering movie, but Carol didn’t have a character arc, the references messed up the MCU timeline, and Carol was convinced that the Skrulls were right and her side was lying all along a bit fast (I know it was a movie and they did the whole memories-gained-back thing but did she really have no suspicion about fake memories being planted in her mind? Did she not think about moments in the past where she was like ‘oh now that I think about it’? But I’m not here to argue about that).

So Captain Marvel was, maybe, around a 7/10 for me, looking at it as just a movie.

But it wasn’t. 

Captain Marvel was the representation that girls so rarely see. Brie Larson was playing a badass who took no shit from anyone. We see a girl who drives a motorcycle, single-handedly takes down a fleet, and yet still chats with a little girl about fashion and sings karaoke with her girlfriend.

We saw a girl who didn’t put down other girls, we saw a girl who got up again and again, and we saw a hero that represented us.

So Captain Marvel wasn’t the greatest. It was no Iron Man (which I know some people disliked but from a film analysis point? Objectively? Character development wise and pacing and everything? So well done.) but it’s the closest we’ve got, which is why it’s so important. Because this might inspire girls to make movies with female leads that are amazing. That are 10/10, that have amazing character development and pacing and are beautiful works of art.

Captain Marvel was great. But it’s not enough. Let’s make well done, popular female-driven movies the norm, to the point where the next generation doesn’t have boys that whine about it because that’s just how it is.

Instead of having one movie that every girl loves because of the representation, let’s make representation so normal, so common that girls can say “well, I didn’t like this movie” with a female lead and that’s fine because there are a million others to choose from, all with women leading.

Captain Marvel did really well because it had great female representation. Let’s keep it up.

So Captain Marvel was, maybe, around a 7/10 for me, looking at it as just a movie.

But it wasn’t. 

Captain Marvel was the representation that girls so rarely see. Brie Larson was playing a badass who took no shit from anyone. We see a girl who drives a motorcycle, single-handedly takes down a fleet, and yet still chats with a little girl about fashion and sings karaoke with her girlfriend.

We saw a girl who didn’t put down other girls, we saw a girl who got up again and again, and we saw a hero that represented us.

So Captain Marvel wasn’t the greatest. It was no Iron Man (which I know some people disliked but from a film analysis point? Objectively? Character development wise and pacing and everything? So well done.) but it’s the closest we’ve got, which is why it’s so important. Because this might inspire girls to make movies with female leads that are amazing. That are 10/10, that have amazing character development and pacing and are beautiful works of art.

Captain Marvel was great. But it’s not enough. Let’s make well done, popular female-driven movies the norm, to the point where the next generation doesn’t have boys that whine about it because that’s just how it is.

Instead of having one movie that every girl loves because of the representation, let’s make representation so normal, so common that girls can say “well, I didn’t like this movie” with a female lead and that’s fine because there are a million others to choose from, all with women leading.

Captain Marvel did really well because it had great female representation. Let’s keep it up.
trail.content:
Let’s be honest, here. Captain Marvel was a fun, vibrant and empowering movie, but Carol didn’t have a character arc, the references messed up the MCU timeline, and Carol was convinced that the Skrulls were right and her side was lying all along a bit fast (I know it was a movie and they did the whole memories-gained-back thing but did she really have no suspicion about fake memories being planted in her mind? Did she not think about moments in the past where she was like ‘oh now that I think about it’? But I’m not here to argue about that).

So Captain Marvel was, maybe, around a 7/10 for me, looking at it as just a movie.

But it wasn’t. 

Captain Marvel was the representation that girls so rarely see. Brie Larson was playing a badass who took no shit from anyone. We see a girl who drives a motorcycle, single-handedly takes down a fleet, and yet still chats with a little girl about fashion and sings karaoke with her girlfriend.

We saw a girl who didn’t put down other girls, we saw a girl who got up again and again, and we saw a hero that represented us.

So Captain Marvel wasn’t the greatest. It was no Iron Man (which I know some people disliked but from a film analysis point? Objectively? Character development wise and pacing and everything? So well done.) but it’s the closest we’ve got, which is why it’s so important. Because this might inspire girls to make movies with female leads that are amazing. That are 10/10, that have amazing character development and pacing and are beautiful works of art.

Captain Marvel was great. But it’s not enough. Let’s make well done, popular female-driven movies the norm, to the point where the next generation doesn’t have boys that whine about it because that’s just how it is.

Instead of having one movie that every girl loves because of the representation, let’s make representation so normal, so common that girls can say “well, I didn’t like this movie” with a female lead and that’s fine because there are a million others to choose from, all with women leading.

Captain Marvel did really well because it had great female representation. Let’s keep it up.

body:
Unicorn Store Ramble

This is just my unsolicited rambling about Unicorn Store but it really made me think because near the end of the film I was confused why the handyman guy still liked the protagonist because she was so weird and immature and kind of emotionally unavailable and I started to feel like it was unrealistic that he was still sticking around, but then I realised, if the genders were reversed, the ‘normal’ woman would 100% be into the 'weird’ man enough to deal with his immature outbursts and noone would bat an eyelid. There are a thousand movies where a man is emotionally immature and the woman just deals with it, so you know what, thank you Brie Larson for creating this scenario where we get to see it the other way around. Thank you for showing us that women can be weird, immature, emotionally stunted, and can still be loveable.

summary:
"is that guacamole on bread?"
Yes, yes it is.
Ok, so now I really want to know: does Brie Larson get sponsorship money for doing...
body:
“is that guacamole on bread?”

Yes, yes it is.

Ok, so now I really want to know: does Brie Larson get sponsorship money for doing ads like these, or are they part of her contractual obligation to Marvel Studios/Disney?

Because I hope she’s getting extra coin.
